February 20, 2017 6:58 pm Updated: February 21, 2017 12:13 am N.B. still considering Family Day, some business leaders express concern By Jeremy Keefe Video Journalist Global News 
WATCH ABOVE: While residents in several provinces enjoyed a day off Monday, it was a typical back to work for New Brunswickers. As Global's Jeremy Keefe reports, while the provincial government hasn't ruled out a February holiday, some think the move would be bad for business. What is this?

READ MORE: Family Day for New Brunswick? The government is considering it 
While seven Canadian provinces observe a February holiday, Quebec, Newfoundland and Labrador and New Brunswick do not. Kelsey Nissen flew in from Toronto for the weekend. Says Family Day gives her a chance to come home and spend time with loved ones. pic.twitter.com/PBq0girmDw 
— Jeremy Keefe (@Jeremy_Keefe) February 20, 2017 
In New Brunswick, the provincial government began floating the idea of instituting a new holiday last year but they still have yet to make a decision for or against. 
“We’re still speaking to many of the stakeholders, we understand how great it would be to have a Family Day here in New Brunswick,” explained Premier Brian Gallant. “We think there are many merits to that, but we also want to make sure that we’re talking with the business community, talking with other stakeholders to see what type of impact it could have on them.” Canadian Manufacturers & Exporters NB/PEI VP Joel Richardson says holiday would add more costs to businesses when economy already struggling pic.twitter.com/SQO9hpwQU1 
— Jeremy Keefe (@Jeremy_Keefe) February 20, 2017 
Joel Richardson, vice president of the Canadian Manufacturers and Exporters, NB & PEI Division said those impacts would be substantial. 
“It’s just a lot of extra costs from the manufacturer’s perspective at a time when the economy really isn’t doing too well,” he said. “New Brunswick’s productivity overall, when you look at how we stack up to the rest of the country, our productivity is actually fairly low. We need to do more work to get more output.” 
“Adding more lost time from a business perspective isn’t necessarily a good idea” 
Gallant said there’s currently no timeline for a decision as they continue to weigh the benefits of the issue. 
“We want to make sure that if we ever do go forward with it that we do everything we can to mitigate the potential negative impacts on some of the stakeholders,” Gallant said. “But our government is still committed to looking deeply into this issue.”
